title: Structure-based Design of Prefusion-stabilized SARS-CoV-2 Spikes
authors: Hsieh CL, Goldsmith JA, Schaub JM, DiVenere AM, Kuo HC, et al.
keyAssumptions: Proline substitutions from SARS-CoV/MERS-CoV directly transferable to SARS-CoV-2
keyHypotheses: Systematic structure-based design can identify optimal stabilization beyond minimal approaches
strengths: Established HexaPro as gold standard; systematic approach; comprehensive validation
weaknesses: Still relies on proline paradigm; limited exploration of alternative mechanisms
citation: Hsieh, C.L., Goldsmith, J.A., Schaub, J.M., DiVenere, A.M., Kuo, H.C., et al. (2020). Structure-based Design of Prefusion-stabilized SARS-CoV-2 Spikes. bioRxiv.
notes: Foundational paper establishing structure-based optimization superiority

title: High-throughput identification of prefusion-stabilizing mutations in SARS-CoV-2 spike
keyAssumptions: Structure-based rational design captures all optimal mutations
keyHypotheses: Systematic unbiased screening reveals non-obvious stabilizing mutations beyond structural prediction
strengths: Unbiased methodology; identifies non-proline alternatives; quantitative approach
weaknesses: Limited to S2 domain; requires specialized methodology
citation: Wu, N.C., et al. (2023). High-throughput identification of prefusion-stabilizing mutations in SARS-CoV-2 spike. Nature Communications 14:1899.
notes: Key paper supporting alternative stabilization mechanisms beyond proline paradigm

title: Enhancing the Prefusion Conformational Stability of SARS-CoV-2 Spike Protein Through Structure-Guided Design
authors: Riley TP, Chou HT, Hu R, Bzymek KP, Correia AR, et al.
keyAssumptions: Moderate stabilization sufficient; over-stabilization reduces immunogenicity
keyHypotheses: Extreme stabilization can enhance rather than compromise immunogenicity
strengths: Demonstrates enhanced immunogenicity with high stability; multiple stabilization mechanisms
citation: Riley, T.P., Chou, H.T., Hu, R., Bzymek, K.P., Correia, A.R., et al. (2021). Enhancing the Prefusion Conformational Stability of SARS-CoV-2 Spike Protein Through Structure-Guided Design. Front. Immunol. 12:660198.
notes: Challenges over-stabilization assumption; supports maximum stability approaches

title: Closing coronavirus spike glycoproteins by structure-guided design
authors: McCallum M, Walls AC, Corti D, Veesler D
keyAssumptions: Prefusion stabilization primarily about overall trimer stability
keyHypotheses: Covalent locking of specific conformational states enables precise control
strengths: Novel disulfide engineering approach; precise conformational control; generalizable method
weaknesses: May over-constrain dynamics; limited immunogenicity data
citation: McCallum, M., Walls, A.C., Corti, D., Veesler, D. (2020). Closing coronavirus spike glycoproteins by structure-guided design. bioRxiv.
notes: Provides alternative to proline paradigm; enables static vs dynamic studies

title: SARS-CoV-2 S Glycoprotein Stabilization Strategies
authors: Pedenko B, Sulbaran G, Guilligay D, Effantin G, Weissenhorn W
keyAssumptions: Individual stabilization approaches work in isolation
keyHypotheses: Systematic framework needed for comparing and optimizing stabilization strategies
strengths: Comprehensive review; classification framework; structure-function emphasis
weaknesses: Review paper limitations; limited novel experimental data
citation: Pedenko, B., Sulbaran, G., Guilligay, D., Effantin, G., Weissenhorn, W. (2023). SARS-CoV-2 S Glycoprotein Stabilization Strategies. Viruses 15(2):558.

title: Impact of SARS-CoV-2 spike stability and RBD exposure on antigenicity and immunogenicity
keyAssumptions: Higher stability always correlates with better immunogenicity; RBD dynamics don't significantly affect immune recognition
keyHypotheses: RBD exposure dynamics are critical for optimal immunogenicity, not just overall stability
strengths: Systematic analysis of stability-immunogenicity relationships; RBD dynamics measurements
citation: Langedijk, J.P.M., et al. (2024). Impact of SARS-CoV-2 spike stability and RBD exposure on antigenicity and immunogenicity. Nat Sci Rep 14:5623.
notes: Validates importance of controlled dynamics over maximum stabilization

title: Prefusion spike protein stabilization through computational mutagenesis
authors: Zhang DY, Wang J, Dokholyan NV
keyAssumptions: Structure-based rational design captures optimal stabilizing mutations
keyHypotheses: Automated computational pipeline can systematically identify stabilizing mutations beyond human intuition
strengths: Systematic computational approach; integration of multiple methods; validated predictions
weaknesses: Requires computational expertise; limited experimental validation
citation: Zhang, D.Y., Wang, J., Dokholyan, N.V. (2020). Prefusion spike protein stabilization through computational mutagenesis. Proteins 88:1864-1874.
notes: Supports systematic screening approaches superior to structure-based design alone

title: Controlling the SARS-CoV-2 Spike Glycoprotein Conformation
authors: Henderson R, Edwards RJ, Mansouri K, et al.
keyAssumptions: Prefusion stabilization approaches provide uniform conformational control; individual mutations work independently
keyHypotheses: Precise conformational control requires understanding of allosteric networks and cooperative effects
strengths: Systematic conformational engineering; cooperative stabilization networks; structural validation
citation: Henderson, R., Edwards, R.J., Mansouri, K., et al. (2020). Controlling the SARS-CoV-2 Spike Glycoprotein Conformation. bioRxiv.

title: A thermostable, closed, SARS-CoV-2 spike protein trimer
authors: Xiong X, Qu K, Ciazynska KA, et al.
keyAssumptions: Simple proline mutations sufficient for stabilization; open conformation necessary for immunogenicity
keyHypotheses: Covalent crosslinking can trap spike in thermostable, closed conformation while retaining function
strengths: Novel covalent engineering approach; thermostable constructs; structural characterization
citation: Xiong, X., Qu, K., Ciazynska, K.A., et al. (2020). A thermostable, closed, SARS-CoV-2 spike protein trimer. bioRxiv.
notes: Provides alternative to proline paradigm and tools for testing static vs dynamic approaches

title: Timeline of changes in spike conformational dynamics in emergent SARS-CoV-2 variants reveal progressive stabilization of trimer stalk with altered NTD dynamics
authors: Braet SM, Buckley TSC, Venkatakrishnan V, Dam KMA, Bjorkman PJ, Anand GS
keyAssumptions: Spike protein dynamics remain constant across variants; mutations primarily affect binding affinity
keyHypotheses: SARS-CoV-2 variants show progressive stabilization with systematic dynamic changes that are evolutionarily selected
strengths: Comprehensive HDX-MS analysis; temporal evolution tracking; quantitative dynamics measurement
weaknesses: Limited to dynamics analysis; lacks functional validation
citation: Braet, S.M., Buckley, T.S.C., Venkatakrishnan, V., et al. (2023). Timeline of changes in spike conformational dynamics in emergent SARS-CoV-2 variants. eLife 12:e82584.
notes: Validates importance of controlled dynamics and variant-specific adaptations
